document.docAuthor: Liao, Jingjing & Xie, Lei & Shi, Hongwu & Cui, Shengrong & Lan, Fusheng & Luo, Zuliang & Ma, Xiaojun
document.docTitle: Development of an efficient transient expression system for Siraitia grosvenorii fruit and functional characterization of two NADPH-cytochrome P450 reductases

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: Development of an efficient transient expression system for Siraitia grosvenorii fruit and functional characterization of two NADPH-cytochrome P450 reductases

mods:name.mods:affiliation: ** & * & Institute of Medicinal Plant Development, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences & Peking Union Medical College, Beijing, 100193, China

docTitle.paragraph:
Development of an efficient transient expression system for
Siraitia grosvenorii
fruit and functional characterization of two NADPH-cytochrome

subSection.paragraph:
Xiaojun Ma
a, *

a
Institute of Medicinal Plant Development, Chinese Academy of Medical Sciences
&
Peking Union Medical College, Beijing , 100193, China

paragraph.emphasis: Guilin GFS Monk Fruit Corp, Guilin, 541006, China

subSection.paragraph: A R T I C L E I N F O
Transient expression
NADPH-Cytochrome P450 reductases Mogrosides
A B S T R A C T

Siraitia grosvenorii
(Luo hanguo or monk fruit) is a valuable medicinal herb for which the market demand has increased dramatically worldwide. As promising natural sweeteners, mogrosides have received much attention from researchers because of their extremely high sweetness and lack of calories. Nevertheless, owing to the absence of genetic transformation methods, the molecular mechanisms underlying the regulation of mogroside biosynthesis have not yet been fully elucidated. Therefore, an effective method for gene function analysis needs to be developed for
S. grosvenorii fruit
. As a powerful approach, transient expression has become a versatile method to elucidate the biological functions of genes and proteins in various plant species. In this study, PBI121 with a β- glucuronidase ( GUS ) marker and tobacco rattle virus (TRV) were used as vectors for overexpression and silencing, respectively, of the SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 genes in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. The effectiveness of transient expression was validated by GUS staining in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, and the expression levels of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 increased significantly after infiltration for 36 h. In addition, TRV-induced gene silencing suppressed the expression of SgCPR1 and
SgCPR 2
in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. More importantly, the production of the major secondary metabolites mogrol, mogroside IIE (MIIE) and mogroside III (MIII) was activated by the overexpression of SgCPR1 and
SgCPR 2
in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, with levels 1–2 times those in the control group. Moreover, the accumulation of mogrol, MIIE and MIII was decreased in the SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 gene silencing assays. Therefore, this transient expression approach was available for
S. grosvenorii fruit
, providing insight into the expression of the SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 genes involved in the mogroside biosynthesis pathway. Our study also suggests that this method has potential applications in the exploration of the molecular mechanisms, biochemical hypotheses and functional characteristics of
S. grosvenorii
genes.

Siraitia grosvenorii (Swingle) C. Jeffrey
is a dioecious medicinal plant of the Cucurbitaceae family that is mainly cultivated in Guilin city, Guangxi Province , China ( Li et al., 2014 ).
S. grosvenorii fruit
contains substantial amounts of triterpenoid, flavonoid, polysaccharide, protein, amino acid and vitamin components ( Jin and Lee, 2012 ) ( Xia et al., 2008 ) ( Qing et al., 2017 ). In particular, mogroside V (MV) has attracted great interest for its low calorie content and high sweetness and is widely used as a natural sweetener in the food and beverage industry (B. Wang et al., 2019). The sweetness of MV is approximately 300-fold that of sucrose. In addition to being used in folk medicine, mogrosides have several kinds of pharmacological characteristics, including anticancer ( Liu et al., 2015 ), anti-hyperglycaemic ( Liu et al., 2018 ), antioxidative ( Takeo et al., 2002 ), anti-inflammatory ( Sung et al., 2019 ) and antidiabetic ( Xu et al., 2020 ) properties. To date, the mogroside biosynthesis pathway has been completely elucidated (Itkin et al., 2016), and a comprehensive
S. grosvenorii
reference genome is available ( Xia et al., 2018 ), facilitating functional gene characterization and genetic improvement. The bulk of enzymes and coding genes responsible for the biosynthesis of mogrosides have been successfully cloned, including squalene epoxidases (Itkin et al., 2016), cucurbitadienol synthase ( Dai et al., 2014 ), epoxide hydrolases (Itkin et al., 2016), cytochrome P450 mono-oxygenase ( CYP 450) ( Zhang et al., 2016 ), NADPH-cytochrome P450 reductases (CPRs) ( Zhao et al., 2018 ), and UDP-glucosyltransferases ( Zhang et al., 2016 ), which are generally identified in microorganisms. Therefore, it is essential to further identify gene function in
S. grosvenorii
. However, transgenic engineering is extremely unstable in
S. grosvenorii
. Consequently, it is important to establish a simple and effective approach to validate genes in
S. grosvenorii
.

In recent years, transient expression has been used in the research of gene functions in many plants with unstable transformation and longer growth periods. In particular,
Agrobacterium
-mediated transient expression and agroinfiltration are simple and widely used approaches to functional gene analysis ( Hellens et al., 2005 ), promoter activity detection ( Tsuda et al., 2012 ; Yang et al., 2000 ), heterologous protein production ( Leuzinger et al., 2013 ; Sainsbury et al., 2009 ; Vink et al., 2014 ) and molecular genetic breeding ( Hussein et al., 2013 ) in plant species. In recent decades, transient expression approaches have been used widely in several kinds of plants, such as
Nicotiana benthamiana ( Norkunas et al., 2018 )
,
Arabidopsis ( Wu et al., 2014 )
,
Spinacia oleracea
L. (Abdoli-nasab and Torabi-nia, 2019), citrus ( Figueiredo et al., 2011 ) and castor (Sanchez-Alvarez ´´et al., 2019). In the Cucurbitaceae family, agroinfiltration has been successfully used in oriental melon ( Liao et al., 2019 ) to express
CmLOX 10
in sprouted seeds and leaves, and transient transformation has been successfully assayed in
Cucumis sativus
cotyledons ( Huang et al., 2013 ). Furthermore, tobacco rattle virus (TRV)-induced gene silencing is a gene knockout method that has been used to validate gene function in several plants, such as
N. benthamiana ( Senthil-Kumar and Mysore, 2014 )
, tomato ( Liu et al., 2002 ), chili pepper ( Chung et al., 2004 )
Arabidopsis thaliana ( Zheng et al., 2011 )
,
Lilium × formolongi
( Xu et al., 2019 ), citrus (F. Wang et al., 2019), and oriental melon ( Liao et al., 2019 ). In addition, transient expression has not yet been reported in
S. grosvenorii
, and the function of key genes was mainly identified in
Saccharomyces cerevisiae
or
Escherichia coli (Itkin et al., 2016)
due to the absence of desirable stable transformation technology in
S. grosvenorii
. This approach provides insight into the molecular characteristics, regulatory mechanism and genetic improvement in
S. grosvenorii
.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 1. The mogroside biosynthetic pathway in
S. grosvenorii
. The blue box on the left shows the generation of mogrol, which is a unique nonglycosylated tetra-hydroxycucurbitane in
S. grosvenorii
. The red box on the right represents a series of glycosylation reactions. The enzyme names are abbreviated as follows: SgSQE , squalene epoxidase; SgCS , cucurbitadienol synthase; SgEPH , epoxide hydrolase; SgCYP450 , cytochrome P450 monooxygenase; SgCPR , NADPHcytochrome P450 reductase; SgUGT , UDP-glucosyltransferase. Among these, the candidate SgCPRs are highlighted in red. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
CYP 450 is responsible for the C3, C11, C24 and C25 hydroxylation required to produce mogrol in the mogroside biosynthesis pathway (Itkin et al., 2016), and CPRs are the essential partners ( Jensen and Møller, 2010 ) ( Fig. 1 ). Plant CYP 450 enzyme function is performed along with CPR function, representing pivotal factors in the conversion of NADPH to electrons via flavin adenine dinucleotide (FAD) and flavin mononucleotide (FMN) to CYP 450 (with a haem-iron group) ( Jensen and Møller, 2010 ; Yang et al., 2010 ). In recent years, various CPRs have been cloned and characterized. Three CPR genes were found in
A. thaliana
, among which the ATR1 and ATR2 genes encoded the active domain of CPRs, while the expression of ATR3 was not able to reduce P450s in vitro ( Mizutani and Ohta, 2010 ; Urban et al., 1994 ; Varadarajan et al., 2010 ). ATR1 expression plays a significant role in alkaloid synthesis in
Capsicum spp.
( Mazourek et al., 2009 ; Sundin et al., 2014 ), and ATR2 is associated with the phenylpropanoid pathway and lignin biosynthesis in
Arabidopsis ( Mizutani and Ohta, 1998 )
. Similarly, the role of
WsCPR 2
in withanolide biosynthesis has been characterized in
Withania somnifera
(L.) Dunal ( Rana et al., 2013 ). In
Gossypium hirsutum , GhCPR
2 is associated with defence responses, such as wounding and secondary metabolite biosynthesis ( Yang et al., 2010 ). Metabolite production was markedly elevated when distinct CYP 450s were accompanied by different CPRs. Previous studies have reported that various plant CYP 450 proteins were accompanied by different CPRs, leading to 1422-fold and 946.5-fold increases in 1-oxo-β- amyrin and glycyrrhetinic acid levels, respectively, in
S. cerevisiae
compared to previous data ( Zhu et al., 2018 ). However, CYP 450 and CPR enzymes could not be efficiently expressed in prokaryotic cells such as
E. coli
as these enzymes are membrane anchored ( Lin et al., 2017 ). Therefore, it is necessary to describe the function of CPRs in
S. grosvenorii
. Overall, transient expression is a particularly noteworthy method for developing a desirable approach to study gene function in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, which has been of interest in plant biochemical and molecular biological research on
S. grosvenorii
.

Herein, a transient expression approach was first developed in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. Overexpression and gene silencing of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 revealed that the SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 expression levels were consistent with mogrol, mogroside IIE (MIIE) and mogroside III (MIII) accumulation. Our results suggested that SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 were of particular importance to mogroside biosynthesis in
S. grosvenorii
. However, in this study, there was no significant difference between SgCPR1 and
SgCPR 2
in terms of mogroside biosynthesis. This study indicated that transient expression can be used in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, providing a versatile alternative tool for exploring the functional characteristics of candidate genes in
S. grosvenorii
. Furthermore, this approach is of great importance for breeding improvement with highcontent mogrosides and produces a vast array of proteins that have advantageous ecological functions.

emphasis.heading: 2.1. Isolation of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 from S. grosvenorii fruit and
recombinant vector construction

subSubSection.paragraph:
In a previous study, SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 were identified in yeast ( Zhao et al., 2018 ). Furthermore, the expression patterns were similar to those of CYP450 enzymes in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, which accumulated at the early stage of fruit development ( Figure S1A and B ). Therefore, SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 were likely to be associated with the mogroside biosynthesis pathway. Therefore, to further investigate SgCPR genes function, the full-length coding sequences (CDSs) of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 were isolated from
S. grosvenorii fruit
using Phanta Max Super-Fidelity DNA Polymerase (Vazyme Biotech Co., Ltd., Nanjing, China ) ( Fig. 2A ), inserted into the cloning vector pMD 19-T (Takara, Dalian, China ), and then ligated into the PBI121 expression vector via the ClonExpress II One Step Cloning Kit (Vazyme Biotech Co., Ltd., Nanjing, China ), producing PBI121- SgCPR1 and PBI121- SgCPR2 . The overexpression of these genes was driven by the 35S promoter with a β- glucuronidase (GUS) reporter ( Fig. 2B ). The PBI121 vector map is shown in Fig. 2C . For virus-induced gene silencing (VIGS) in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, specific regions of the SgCPR1 (391 bp) and SgCPR2 (389 bp) genes were selected by sequence alignment using DNAman software ( Fig. 3A ) and then ligated into the (391 bp and 389 bp, respectively) pTRV2 vector (to obtain pTRV- SgCPR1 and pTRV- SgCPR2 , respectively) ( Fig. 3B ). The accuracy of expression vector cloning was determined by sequencing (Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd., Shanghai ).

heading.emphasis: 2.2. Transient expression of SgCPR1 and SgCPR 2 in S. grosvenorii fruit

subSection.paragraph:
To assess the efficiency of the transient expression system in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, GUS staining was performed at 48 h after agroinfiltration. In this study, untreated wild-type (WT) fruit was used as a negative control. As shown in Fig. 4 , PBI121 had significant GUS expression compared with the WT, which indicated that the overexpression constructs were expressed in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. In addition,
Agrobacterium tumefaciens
containing the PBI121 plasmid was infiltrated into
S. grosvenorii
leaves using a sterile syringe without a needle. However, GUS expression was present only in trace amounts around the injection sites, which revealed that the transient expression system was unavailable in
S. grosvenorii
leaves ( Fig. 4C ). The expression levels of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 were six- and fivefold higher than those in the empty vector group after infiltration for 36 h ( Fig. 5A and B ). These results suggested that this transient expression strategy was suitable for
S. grosvenorii fruit
.

The gene silencing efficiency of VIGS in
S. grosvenorii fruit
was estimated by gene expression level analysis using qRT-PCR. The results showed that the transcript levels of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 were significantly decreased at 36 h post infiltration. The SgCPR1 gene expression level was significantly decreased (fourfold) compared with that of pTRV-0 ( Fig. 5C ). Simultaneously, the expression of SgCPR2 was decreased, being approximately threefold lower than that of pTRV-0 ( Fig. 5D ). These data suggested that the expression of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 was suppressed in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. At 14 d post infiltration, the fruit turned yellow and soft and became decayed, which was caused by
Agrobacterium tumefaciens
. In this case, the expression levels were not detected. To some extent, this strategy achieved efficient gene silencing in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. The efficiency of VIGS in infected plants was up to 72.5%.

Taken together, these results clearly showed that agroinfiltration has potential as a versatile approach for candidate gene identification in
S. grosvenorii fruit
.

The mogroside biosynthesis pathway was elucidated in
S. grosvenorii
by Itkin (Itkin et al., 2016), and two SgCPRs were identified ( Zhao et al., 2018 ). The impact of the SgCPRs on mogroside accumulation in
S. grosvenorii fruit
has yet to be studied. Here, a transient expression system was successfully established in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, via which the gene expression level could be increased or decreased effectively. To further verify the SgCPR function responsible for mogroside biosynthesis, the levels of major mogrosides were quantified by LC-MS ( Fig. 6 ). However, mogroside IV (MIV), MV and mogroside V (MVI) were not found because the green fruit were suitable for infiltration by
A. tumefaciens
with recombinant vectors. In addition, mogroside IA1 (MIA1) was rare and could not be detected. Hence, in this study, mogrol, MIIE and MIII were quantified. For mogrol, the retention time was 6.43 min. The peaks of PBI121- SgCPR1 and PBI121- SgCPR2 were significantly higher than that of PBI121. Similarly, the peaks of pTRV- SgCPR1 and pTRV- SgCPR2 were lower than that of the control ( Fig. 7 and Fig. 8 ). MIIE and MIII were identified according to the retention time (10.01 and 12.09 min, respectively) and product ion (m/z 961.6/799.4 and 799.5/637.5, respectively) ( Fig. 6 ). The levels of mogrol, MIIE and MIII were significantly higher in
S. grosvenorii fruit
with PBI121- SgCPR1 and PBI121- SgCPR2 compared to PBI121, by approximately 2-3-fold at 36 h and 48 h post infiltration ( Fig. 9A, B and C ), whereas the accumulation of mogrol, MIIE and MIII decreased approximately 3-4-fold only at 2 d post infiltration ( Fig. 9D, E and F ). It is likely that fruit decay has a negative influence on the expression of recombinant vectors. These combined results showed that SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 expression levels were associated with mogroside accumulation in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, playing a critical role in mogroside biosynthesis in this fruit.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 2. (A) Cloning of full-length and specific fragments of the SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 genes from
S. grosvenorii
cDNA. M, marker (2000 bp). The fulllength SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 genes are shown in red brackets, whereas the blue arrow indicates the specific fragments of the SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 genes. (B) Vector map of PBI121. (C) Construction of PBI12- SgCPR recombinant plasmids with the GUS marker and CaMV35S promoter. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

Fig. 3. (A) Selective nucleotide sequences for VIGS in
S. grosvenorii
, which were inserted into Eco RI and Bam HI. (B) pTRV2- SgCPR recombinant plasmid construction.

Fig. 4. Histochemical GUS assay of transient expression in
S. grosvenorii
. GUS expression was detected in fruit but not in CK or leaves.

subSection.paragraph:
To overcome the obstacle of an unstable transformation system, an efficient transient expression approach was carried out in
S. grosvenorii fruit
( Figure S1 ). Agroinfiltration was used to infect the cotyledon, leaf and fruit, and GUS staining was applied to determine the suitability of transient expression. It was difficult to infiltrate leaves with
Agrobacterium
via syringe because several leaves had blades that were abaxially tomentose. It was essential to select more suitable leaves that were conducive to infiltration by a needleless syringe, but unfortunately, GUS staining revealed that the recombinant vector was not expressed in any of the leaves ( Fig. 4C ) and cotyledons (data not listed). Notably, a transient expression approach was successfully used in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. As expected, the expression level and GUS histochemical staining analyses confirmed that this approach was available and effective in
S. grosvenorii fruit
with PBI121- SgCPR1 and PBI121- SgCPR2 . To date, transient expression has not been used in any medicinal herbs except
Salvia miltiorrhiza
and
Prunella vulgaris ( Xia et al., 2020 )
. More importantly, this method is valuable for the Cucurbitaceae family, and we also used the PBI121 empty vector to infiltrate bitter melon. Interestingly, bitter melon also showed strong GUS staining (data not listed), so the method could apparently be used to perform biochemical hypothesis testing for fruits of the Cucurbitaceae family. As a powerful transient silencing tool, TRV-induced gene silencing has been successfully used in a broad range of plant species ( Liao et al., 2017 ). Nevertheless, this method has rarely been applied in medicinal herbs. Here, we silenced the SgCPRs in
S. grosvenorii
, and at 14 d post infiltration, severe decay was observed in the infiltrated fruit, which had a mild effect on metabolite detection, but this was a common symptom of VIGS . It was reported that other vectors were associated with more severe symptoms ( Liao et al., 2017 ) ( Zeng et al., 2019 ). The approach described here is a breakthrough for important organisms in which the use of conventional genetic transformation is limited. This approach allows simple and rapid screening of candidate genes and functional protein expression in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. In addition, mogrosides are mainly present in the fruit; thus, this approach has been widely applied in gene analysis and plays a key role in the study of mogroside biosynthesis, functional protein expression and cellular localization in
S. grosvenorii
.

A previous study have suggested that CPRs are indispensable for CYP 450 expression ( Sintupachee et al., 2014 ), and in various plant species, the coexpression patterns of CYP 450s and CPRs have been estimated, including in
S. miltiorrhiza ( Guo et al., 2013 )
,
Papaver somniferum ( Rosco et al., 1997 )
and
A. thaliana ( Christ et al., 2013 )
. Generally, mammals harbour only one CPR ( Guengerich, 1994 ), but one to four CPRs have been found in plants ( Eberle et al., 2009 ; Shet et al., 1993 ), making it more difficult to determine the function of each CPR. Moreover, numerous plant CYP 450s and CPRs have been previously identified and expressed in yeasts ( Hamann and Møller, 2007 ; Jennewein et al., 2005 ; Urban et al., 1997 ) and have rarely been reported in plant-associated prokaryotic species. Therefore, in our study, we first expressed SgCPRs in
S. grosvenorii
via a transient expression system. SgCPR expression levels were significantly increased or decreased in the PBI121- SgCPRs or pTRV- SgCPRs , respectively. The major metabolites mogrol, MIIE and MIII showed slight increases and decreases, respectively, although there was no increase in the SgCYP450 expression levels ( Figure S3 ). However, CPRs are the molecular chaperones for CYP 450, not the regulatory factors, so it was reasonable that the SgCYP450 expression levels remained unaffected. Notably, SgCPRs play pivotal roles in the mogroside biosynthesis pathway, which provides a novel approach for gene discovery in
S. grosvenorii
and will facilitate synthetic biological research on mogrosides.

caption.paragraph: Fig. 5. qRT-PCR analysis of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 in fruit after infiltration (at t =0 h). Relative expression levels were normalized to t = 0 h. (A) Relative transcript levels of SgCPR1 in fruit harbouring PBI121- SgCPR1 and PBI121. (B) SgCPR2 gene expression levels in fruit harbouring PBI121 and PBI121- SgCPR2 . (C) Relative expression levels of SgCPR1 in fruit harbouring pTRV- SgCPR1 and pTRV-0. (D) Expression levels of SgCPR2 in fruit harbouring pTRV- SgCPR2 and pTRV-0. The relative expression levels normalized to the level of the SgUBQ gene. All the data are shown as means±SDs. * indicates significant differences at p < 0.05 (LSD test).

Fig. 6. Accumulation of MIII and MIIE. (A) Total ion chromatograms of ten standard mixtures determined by LC-MS/MS. Among these, the retention times of MIII and MIIE were 10.01 and 12.09 min, respectively. (B) Extracted ion chromatograms of the sample. The red arrow indicates the Q1/Q3 mass chromatograms of MIII, which are in the red box. The Q1/Q3 mass chromatograms of MIIE are shown in the blue box, as indicated by the blue arrow. (For interpretation of the references to color in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the Web version of this article.)

subSection.paragraph:
Generally, a rapid and efficient transient expression strategy has been successfully deployed in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, representing a practical and promising technology for efficient gene function analysis and protein expression. Importantly, this powerful tool can overcome the pathway in
S. grosvenorii
. Above all, this approach is considered an attractive strategy to overcome the limitations associated with the absence of a stable transformation system and could be used to explore valuable candidate genes and the molecular mechanism of mogroside biosynthesis in
S. grosvenorii
.

The fruit of
Siraitia grosvenorii (Swingle) C. Jeffrey (Cucurbitaceae)
(Luo hanguo) used in this study was green fruit, which was cultivated in open fields of Yongfu district in Guangxi Province of China (
109 ◦ 59 ′ 59 ′′ E
;
24 ◦ 59 ′ 48 ′′ N
). All plants were infiltrated at 20 d after pollination. limitations associated with the absence of a stable genetic transformation system, accelerating the elucidation of molecular mechanisms and providing effective tools for genetic engineering. In the future, the role of functional genes and regulatory genes such as transcription factors will be further investigated in
S. grosvenorii fruit
via a transient expression approach, which will allow increased mogroside production to be achieved in the future.

caption.paragraph:
Fig. 7. HPLC chromatogram of the mogrol standard and
Agrobacterium
-mediated transient expression of fruit harbouring PBI121- SgCPRs and PBI121 at 24 h after agroinfiltration.

Fig. 8. HPLC chromatogram of the mogrol standard and
Agrobacterium
-mediated transient expression of fruit harbouring pTRV- SgCPRs and pTRV-0 at 24 h after agroinfiltration.

subSection.paragraph:
As a natural sweetener and valuable edible and medicinal herb,
S. grosvenorii fruit
(Luo hanguo) has a large market worldwide. However, research on its molecular mechanisms has lagged due to the absence of a stable transformation system. In our study, as a versatile functional gene analysis approach, the use of transient expression was first established in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. The initiation factors associated with CYP 450 gene function, namely, SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 , were overexpressed and exhibited significant silencing, which demonstrated that SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 played an important role in mogrol, MIIE and MIII accumulation in
S. grosvenorii fruit
. This study further revealed that SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 were involved in the mogroside biosynthetic
5.2. Vector construction

The open reading frames of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 (accession numbers MH886510.1 and MH886511.1, respectively) were amplified from cDNA of ‘NongYuan B6’ fruit (all primers are listed in Table S 1). Full-length SgCPR1 and SgCPR2 were cloned into the PBI121 expression vector carrying a CaMV 35 S promoter-driven GUS reporter protein, and specific fragments of 391 bp and 389 bp of SgCPR1 and SgCPR2, respectively, were ligated into pTRV2 to generate pTRV- SgCPR1 and pTRV- SgCPR2 , respectively ( Fig. 2B ). All the expression vectors were confirmed by PCR and sequencing (Sangon Biotech Co., Ltd., Shanghai ).

A. tumefaciens
strain GV3101 harbouring the recombinant vectors was used for agroinfiltration in
S. grosvenorii fruit
with an empty vector as a control. The
Agrobacterium
cultures were cultured in 5 mL of yeast extract broth (YEB) with 30 mg /L rifampicin and 50 mg /L kanamycin overnight on a 28 ◦ C shaker. The overnight cultured suspension was grown in 50 mL of Luria-Bertani medium (1:10 (v/v) ratio) with 30 mg / L rifampicin, 50 mg /L kanamycin, 10 mM M2-(N-morpholino) ethanesulfonic acid (MES) and 100 μM acetosyringone ( AS ) to OD 600 = 0.6–0.7. The bacterial cultures were harvested and resuspended in 50 mL of MMA buffer, containing 10 mM MgCl 2 , 10 mM MES and 100 μM AS , which were dissolved in sterile water. Then, the bacterial cultures were incubated at room temperature for 3 h in the dark before infiltration. To facilitate infiltration, all fruit were marked with a cross near the stalk using a sterile syringe ( Figure S1 ). Approximately 500 μL of
Agrobacterium
mixture was infiltrated into each fruit, and all fruit were held for 12 h in the dark after infiltration. Transient expression was examined at 0, 12, 24, 36 and 48 h for gene expression quantification analysis after infiltration. In particular, in the VIGS assay, pTRV2, pTRVSgCPR2 and pTRV- SgCPR2 were mixed at 1:1 (v/v) with pTRV1 before infiltration. The silencing effectiveness of VIGS in
S. grosvenorii fruit
was assayed from 0 h to 30 d after inoculation. The injection site in the
S. grosvenorii fruit
was sampled and kept in liquid nitrogen.

To study the efficiency of transient expression in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, GUS staining was used in this experiment. GUS staining was performed at 36 h post infiltration for fruit with PBI121 and CK as described previously ( Jefferson et al., 1987 ). Briefly, X-gluc (Thermo Fisher Scientific, USA ) was dissolved in EDTA⋅Na 2 , Triton X-100, and K 3 Fe(CN) 6 . Fruit samples were submerged in this solution at 37 ◦ C for 12 h. After staining, 100%, 95% and 75% ethanol solutions were used for decolorization for 10 min. Images were obtained using a Canon EOS 80D. Each experiment was performed in triplicate.

S. grosvenorii fruit
harbouring PBI121, PBI121- SgCPR1 , and PBI121- SgCPR2 . (B) MIIE content in the

harbouring PBI121, PBI121- SgCPR1 , and PBI121- SgCPR2 . (C) MIII content in the
S. grosvenorii fruit
harbouring PBI121, PBI121- SgCPR1 , and PBI121- SgCPR2 . (D) Accumulation of mogrol in the
S. grosvenorii fruit
harbouring pTRV, pTRV- SgCPR1 , and pTRV- SgCPR2 . (E) Accumulation of MII in the
S. grosvenorii fruit
harbouring pTRV, pTRV- SgCPR1 , and pTRV- SgCPR2 . (F) Accumulation of MIII in the
S. grosvenorii fruit
harbouring pTRV, pTRV- SgCPR1 , and pTRV- SgCPR2 . The values are the mean ±SD of three independent biological replicates.

heading.emphasis: 5.5. RNA extraction and quantitative RT-PCR assay

subSection.paragraph:
In this experiment, total RNA was isolated from
S. grosvenorii fruit
post infiltration using a CWbio RNA extraction kit (Cat# CW0581, CWbio Co., Ltd., Beijing , China ), and 1 μg of RNA was reverse transcribed to cDNA via TransScript ® One-Step gDNA Removal and cDNA Synthesis SuperMix (Transgen, Beijing , China ). Quantitative RT-PCR (qRT-PCR) was carried out using
PerfectStart TM
Green qPCR SuperMix (Transgen, Beijing , China ) with an ABI CFX96™ Real-Time System ( USA ) to quantify the relative transcript levels. All primers for qRT-PCR are listed in Table S 1. Among these, SgUBQ was used as an internal control and was used to normalize the gene transcript levels. Relative quantitative analysis was performed using the 2 ΔΔCT method. Each experiment was performed in triplicate.

A total of 0.50 g of dry powder of
S. grosvenorii fruit
was mixed with 25 mL of 80% methanol solution containing 5% (w/v) potassium hydroxide using ultrasonic extraction at 40 kHz and room temperature for 1 h, and then, methanol solution was added to make up for the loss. After centrifugation, the supernatant was retained and enriched. The concentrated solution was dissolved in methanol and filtered using a 0.25 μM filter membrane.

A 4000 QTRAP® LC-MS/MS instrument (AB Sciex, Toronto, Canada ) was used for LC-MS/MS detection, along with an Agilent Technologies 1260 Series LC system (Agilent, USA ) equipped with an Agilent Poroshell 120 SB C18 column ( 100 mm × 2.1 mm , 2.7 μm). Gradient elution was performed using a mobile phase consisting of (A) water (containing 0.1% formic acid) and (B) acetonitrile (containing 0.1% formic acid). The HPLC method for MIA1, MIIE and MIII detection was as follows: 0–8 min, 25% B; 11 min, 80% B; 11.01–11.50 min, 80% B; and 11.51–20 min, 20% B. The flow rate was 0.25 mL/min. Similarly, to determine the mogrol content in
S. grosvenorii fruit
, the HPLC method was as follows: 0–0.3 min, 2% B; 1.5–3.0 min, 30% B; 4.2 min, 98% B; and 4.2–7.0 min, 2% B. The flow rate was 0.20 mL/min.

The LC-MS/MS parameters are listed in Table S 2, and electrospray ionization (ESI) was used in this experiment. The detection mode was multiple reaction monitoring (MRM) scanning. The electrospray voltage, source temperature, curtain gas (CUR), nebulizer gas (GS1), heater gas (GS2), precursor ion, product ion, declustering potential (DP), entrance potential (EP), collision energy (CE), and collision cell exit potential (CXP) are listed in Table S 2. Each experiment was performed in triplicate.
All standards were purchased from Chengdu Must Bio-Technology Co., Ltd. ( Sichuan , China ) and dissolved in methanol.

Random sampling was carried out in this study. Data analysis was performed with the SPSS 13.0 statistics program, and SPSS 16.0 was used to calculate the averages, standard deviations and significant differences. All plots were obtained using Origin Pro 8.
All authors declare no conflict of interest.

This work was supported by the NSFC Joint Fund (NO. U20A2004), the National Natural Science Foundation of China (81973413), the Science and Technology Major Project of Guangxi (GuiKeAA19254025) and the CAMS Innovation Fund for Medical Sciences (NO. 2019-1007- 15).
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2021.112824.
